conclusion: Understanding the setup of the particle accelerator with alternating connections to an AC power supply.
Voltage alternates between +U and -U, odd-numbered cylinders are at higher potential at t=0.
Electron starts from rest at the center of a metal plate connected to even-numbered cylinders.
The goal is to find the length of the nth cylinder to ensure continuous acceleration in the gaps.
Electron is negatively charged, so it will be accelerated towards the positive potential.
Electric field in the gap is uniform, acceleration is constant within that gap.
Electric field inside the cylinders is zero, so no acceleration there; acceleration only happens in the gaps.
Voltage alternates every T seconds, switching from +U to -U and back.
Electron moves at constant velocity inside the cylinders.
Electron should exit cylinder 1 just as the voltage switches to -U to ensure acceleration in the next gap.
Synchronize the electron's passage through each cylinder with the voltage cycle.
Electron enters each gap when the voltage is such that the next cylinder has the higher potential, ensuring acceleration.
At t=0, voltage is +U, so cylinder 1 is positive relative to the starting plate.
Electron moves from plate to cylinder 1, gaining speed.
Inside cylinder 1, electron moves at constant velocity v1, taking time t1 = L1/v1.
After exiting cylinder 1, electron enters the gap between cylinder 1 and 2.
At this point, voltage should still be +U, so cylinder 2 should be at lower potential, attracting the electron.
Cylinder 2 is connected to the other pole, which at t=0 is at -U relative to cylinder 1.
In figure 1, cylinders 1,3,5,7 are connected together, and 2,4 are connected together.
